channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Nobel Peace Prize That Paved the Way for War in Ethiopia
item.description: This is the story behind how Ethiopia’s prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, won a Nobel Prize for making peace with his country’s longtime enemy — and then used the alliance to plan a war.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia won early acclaim for his promise to unify his country.

item.title: North Korea Executes People for Watching K-Pop, Rights Group Says
item.description: At least seven people have been put to death in the past decade for watching or distributing K-pop videos, as the North cracks down on what its leader calls a “vicious cancer.”
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, has at times tried to appear more flexible toward outside culture​. In 2018, he invited South Korean musicians to a rare concert in Pyongyang.

item.title: Russian Is Convicted in Murder of Chechen Man in a Berlin Park
item.description: A German court ruled that the Russian state had orchestrated the attack, which strained ties between Berlin and Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Christoph Soeder/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers at the site in Berlin where Zelimkhan Khangoshvili was killed in 2019.

item.title: Jacob Zuma Must Return to Prison, South Africa Judge Rules
item.description: The former president had been granted medical parole two months into a 15-month prison sentence on contempt charges linked to a corruption inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Jacob Zuma in court in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, in October. A judge ruled on Wednesday that the former president’s health had not “deteriorated permanently or reached an irreversible state.”

item.title: India's Supreme Court Mandates Benefits for Sex Workers
item.description: Officials must enter them into databases for voting and benefits, the judges said, after they suffered from the effects of Covid-19 lockdowns.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: A sex worker in a red light area of Sangli in the western state of Maharashtra, India, in June.

item.title: Blinken Halts Asia Trip After Journalist Tests Positive for Covid
item.description: Citing the need for caution, the secretary of state expressed “deep regret” to Thailand’s deputy prime minister before returning to the United States earlier than planned.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken arriving in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Gasoline Truck in Haiti Explodes, Killing More Than 60
item.description: Scores more were injured in the blast, the latest tragedy to hit a country that has been rocked by political violence, natural disasters, poverty and hunger.
item.dc:creator: Harold Isaac and Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: The remains of the truck, left, that exploded in Cap-Haïtien on Tuesday.

item.title: Conservatives Abandon Johnson Over New Covid Rules
item.description: A record number of Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s fellow party members voted against his plan for Covid certificates. But the plan passed with the help of the opposition.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters demonstrated against Covid-19 passports and increased restrictions on Monday outside Parliament in London.

item.title: Hundreds Trapped by Fire at World Trade Center in Hong Kong
item.description: The blaze at the World Trade Center in Causeway Bay injured at least 13 people, including one who was semiconscious, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: A firefighter rescuing people trapped after a fire broke out at the World Trade Center in Hong Kong on Wednesday.

item.title: E.U. Proposes Changes That Would Chip Away at Borderless Model
item.description: The plan would institutionalize internal border controls to respond to emergencies, suspending some protections for asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Soldiers near Szudzialowo, Poland, last week along the border with Belarus. Poland has been repelling asylum seekers trying to enter E.U. territory through Belarus.

item.title: How Inflation Affects Turkey's Struggling Economy
item.description: Even before the pandemic, Turkey was trying to ward off financial meltdown. The crisis has accelerated as President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has doubled down on his unorthodox policies.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: People lined up to purchase bread in Istanbul, Turkey, last week.

item.title: Boat Carrying Indonesian Migrants Sinks Near Malaysia, Killing at Least 11
item.description: The vessel capsized near a beach town in the South China Sea, leaving 25 others missing, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Hadi Azmi and Mike Ives
item.media:description: A photo made available by the Royal Malaysian Army showed rescuers near a capsized boat on Tanjung Balau Beach in Kota Tinggi, Johor State, Malaysia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Belarus Opposition Leader Is Sentenced to 18 Years in Prison
item.description: The activist Sergei Tikhanovsky planned to challenge the country’s authoritarian leader, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, in a presidential election last year. He was arrested before the vote and his wife stepped in.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The opposition activist Sergei Tikhanovsky, right, with co-defendants at a detention center in Gomel, Belarus, on Tuesday.

item.title: Iran Agrees to Replace Cameras at Nuclear Site but Blocks Images
item.description: Iran’s failure to allow the U.N. nuclear agency to fully monitor its nuclear program is hindering talks in Vienna on restoring the 2015 nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: EU Delegation In Vienna, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Talks in Vienna aimed at restoring the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran are going badly.

item.title: On Cruise Ships, Omicron Puts Safety Protocols to the Test
item.description: Many lines are adjusting their masking, testing and vaccine rules, while criticism is mounting about the lack of transparency in reporting positive cases to passengers and crew members.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:credit: James D. DeCamp/Zuma Press Wire, via Newscom
item.media:description: The Norwegian Breakaway, docked in New Orleans in November. The Norwegian Cruise Line ship reported 17 coronavirus cases the first week of December.

item.title: France Refused to Repatriate a Sick Woman Who Joined the Islamic State. She Died.
item.description: A Frenchwoman died of health complications in a detention camp in Syria on Tuesday, her lawyer said. She had repeatedly asked to be repatriated to treat severe diabetes.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A woman walking through Roj, the camp where relatives of people suspected of belonging to the Islamic State are being detained in Syria’s northeastern Hasakah Province.

item.title: Malta Becomes First E.U. Country to Legalize Marijuana
item.description: The government said that the new law was aimed at ending the criminalization of people for smoking the drug and at reducing criminal trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Malta’s new rules allow people to carry up to seven grams of marijuana, grow up to four plants in their apartments and keep up to 50 grams of dried cannabis at home.

item.title: Vaccine Opponents in Germany Investigated Over Plot to Kill State Governor
item.description: The authorities in Dresden raided the homes of a group of people who they said were targeting the leader of the state of Saxony. A number of weapons were seized.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Police officers leading a suspect out of a building in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday.

item.title: 5 Republican Governors Seek Vaccine Exemptions for National Guard Troops
item.description: The move comes as the Pentagon released a new order this week saying that National Guard members who do not get vaccinated would receive a general order of reprimand, essentially ending their careers.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Wyoming National Guard at the U.S. Capitol in Washington in February.

item.title: Two Doses of China's Sinovac Inadequate Against Omicron, Hong Kong Study Suggests
item.description: Laboratory experiments suggest that the Chinese vaccine provides little protection against an Omicron infection.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and John Liu
item.media:description: Lining up to receive China’s Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine at a community inoculation center in Hong Kong last month.

item.title: 2021 in Photos
item.description: It’s time to look at the Pictures of the Year.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

item.title: Putin and Xi Hold Video Summit
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Xi Jinping of China, meeting in a video summit, sought mutual support in their conflicts with the West but have not yet declared a formal alliance.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Xi Jinping, the leader of China, in 2019 in Brazil. The two leaders are presenting a united front against Western pressure.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Results from Pfizer’s Covid pill.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Pfizer, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A pill of Paxlovid, Pfizer’s Covid treatment, inside a laboratory in Germany. Experts are hopeful Paxlovid could treat the worst of the disease, no matter the variant.

item.title: Trends in Arctic Report Card: ‘Consistent, Alarming and Undeniable’
item.description: The changes happening at the top of the planet could unfold elsewhere in the years to come, scientists report.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.category: National Snow and Ice Data Center
item.media:description: A prowling polar bear on the island of Pyramiden, part of the Svalbard archipelago in Norway, this year.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Pfizer’s Covid Pill
item.description: The company says it prevents severe illness.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Doses of Pfizer’s Paxlovid medication, which the pharmaceutical manufacturer says can protect coronavirus patients from severe effects of the Omicron variant.

item.title: Britain lifts ban on travelers arriving from southern Africa
item.description: With the Omicron variant already spreading, officials conclude they’ve lost the battle to prevent its entering Britain.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: International passengers walk through the arrivals area at Heathrow Airport, in London, on Nov. 26.

item.title: Italian Bishop Gives Children Harsh News: There Is No Santa Claus
item.description: You’ve been lied to, children heard from a bishop, the latest Catholic clergyman to try to take down Santa Claus and consumerism. Many Italians were not pleased.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: A Santa Claus in Turin, Italy, in 2020.

item.title: Three Jailed in Greece After a Principal was Handcuffed Over Virus Measures
item.description: Police said a group of people handcuffed the principal on Friday and drove him to a local precinct, suggesting that officers arrest him for enforcing Covid measures.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: A junior high school in Athens in May.

item.title: Four people are arrested in India after a man leaves the country using a fake virus test result.
item.description: The man, a 66-year-old South African pharmaceutical executive, fled his quarantine hotel and was later confirmed to have the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Kempegowda International Airport in Bengaluru, India. A traveler from South Africa who tested positive on arrival in the city used a falsified negative test to leave, the police said.

item.title: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte Won't Run for Senate
item.description: The populist president also promised a peaceful transition of power when his term ends next year.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Lisa Marie David
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines in July in Manila.

item.title: Illnesses Tied to Omicron May Be Milder, Preliminary Study Suggests
item.description: The findings, which also show that the new variant partly dodges the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, are based on only three weeks of data. Epidemiologists cautioned that the full picture is still emerging.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Scientists Melva Mlambo, right, and Puseletso Lesofi, sequence Omicron samples at the Ndlovu Research Center in Elandsdoorn, South Africa, last week.

item.title: Blinken, in Indonesia, Stresses Soft Power to Counter China
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state seeks to make the case that the United States is a better bet as a partner than China, even if it’s not spending so lavishly in the region.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken speaking about the Biden administration’s Indo-Pacific strategy at the Universitas Indonesia in Jakarta on Tuesday.

item.title: Omicron is a dress rehearsal for the next pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: Molecular biology technician Sarah Corcoran prepares SARS-CoV-2 samples, Omicron, as part of the RNA sequencing process at Ohio State University, where the variant was identified in several samples from Ohio.

item.title: How Far Will Supreme Court Justices Go on Abortion?
item.description: And the Supreme Court’s two very different paths.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: The Supreme Court

item.title: A second Omicron case in China raises the prospect of stricter controls.
item.description: Though both Omicron cases were quarantined upon arrival, a small outbreak in a building where one man was quarantining highlights how difficult it may be to control the new variant.
item.dc:creator: John Liu
item.media:description: Waiting at a testing center in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Why a Times Reporter Keeps Writing About Dive Bars
item.description: Attracted to the grit, equality and community of those modest watering holes, a Times reporter has worked them into his coverage.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Rio de Janeiro, people of all stripes gather in “dirty feet” bars. A reporter recognized a spirit found in other places he had written about.

item.title: Omicron Is a Dress Rehearsal for the Next Pandemic
item.description: America’s response to the variant highlights both how much progress we have made over the past two years — and how much work remains.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Two years of pandemic despair.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Covid-19 patient in a hospital in Marseille, France, on Friday.

item.title: Israel Finds Planes That Could Be Key to a Strike on Iran Badly Back-Ordered
item.description: The United States told Israel it was unlikely to deliver refueling tankers before 2024, amid tensions between the two nations over how to deal with Iran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Ronen Bergman and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: A United States Air Force KC-46 jet in flight this year. KC-46 refueling tankers could prove critical to Israel in efforts to strike Iran’s nuclear facilities.

item.title: Tunisia’s President Promises Vote on Constitution and Sets Election Date
item.description: President Kais Saied’s announcement dispelled some of the uncertainty Tunisians have endured for months since he shunted aside Parliament in what critics called a soft coup.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: President Kais Saied of Tunisia in 2019.

item.title: Russia Blocks U.N. Move to Treat Climate as Security Threat
item.description: The Russian veto of a widely supported Security Council resolution pointed to the difficulty of achieving a unified response to global warming.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Piotr Redlinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Security Council chamber at the United Nations.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Almost 800,000 U.S. Covid Deaths
item.description: People 65 and older are the most vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: A man walked through a memorial installation honoring Los Angeles residents who have died from the coronavirus, last month.

item.title: Denmark and Norway Predict Drastic Spike in Omicron Cases
item.description: Health authorities in Europe are warning of a sharp increase in Omicron cases, adding to an existing surge from the Delta variant.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer and Emily Anthes
item.media:description: Vaccinations at a high school in Oslo in September. Researchers are concerned that the rise in Omicron cases in Norway will overburden hospitals.

item.title: At Least 50 Million Total Coronavirus Cases Have Been Found in the U.S.
item.description: It is almost certainly a substantial undercount, since many infected people have no symptoms or mistake them for those of another illness, and not everyone gets tested.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Photo by Aaron Lavinsky/Star Tribune, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Terry Reynolds, 66, praying last week at the bedside of his wife, Carolyn, 69, in the South Seven Intensive Care Unit of North Memorial Health Hospital in Robbinsdale, Minn. They were both unvaccinated against the coronavirus.

item.title: Boris Johnson Is in Trouble. The Question Is, How Much?
item.description: The British prime minister is facing a new virus variant, a rebellious Conservative Party, collapsing poll ratings and questions about whether he or his staff flouted the lockdown rules.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators rallied in London on Saturday against Covid passports and increasing measures to prevent the spread of the virus.

item.title: Militants Kill 2 Policemen in Kashmir as Violence Escalates
item.description: The clash on Monday came three days after a similar attack on a squad of police officers patrolling streets in northern Kashmir left two of its men dead.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: A protest on the outskirts of Srinagar, Kashmir, on Monday, after deadly clashes between the police and militants.

item.title: Swiss Prosecutors Drop Money-Laundering Case Against Former Spanish King
item.description: A criminal inquiry into allegations that Spain’s former king laundered illegal commission payments from Saudi Arabia related to a high-speed rail deal was closed because of insufficient evidence.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Spain’s former king, Juan Carlos, in 2018.

item.title: Vicente Fernández, the King of Machos and Heartbreak
item.description: The singer’s brand of machismo may have frayed, but for many, he was the ideal of what it means to be hard-working, hard-loving Mexican man.
item.dc:creator: Maira Garcia
item.media:description: The singer Vicente Fernández, who was the king of ranchera music, performed at the Latin Grammy Awards in 2019. He died on Sunday at 81.

item.title: Former Immigration Minister in Denmark Sentenced to Prison for Separating Couples
item.description: Inger Stojberg was sentenced to two months’ incarceration after being found by a court to have illegally ordered the separations of married migrant couples in which at least one person was underage.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Erdbrink and Jasmina Nielsen
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Martin Sylvest/Ritzau Scanpix, via AFP - Getty Images
item.media:description: Inger Stojberg, the former immigration minister, in September. She has said that the separations were aimed at protecting women.

item.title: Merck’s Covid Pill Might Pose Risks for Pregnant Women
item.description: Some laboratory studies suggest that molnupiravir can insert errors in DNA, which could in theory harm a developing fetus, sperm cells or children.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Merck, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: While molnupiravir has been shown to reduce the risk of hospitalization and death from Covid-19, scientists have raised concerns about the drug’s potential to cause mutations in human DNA.

item.title: How Conflicting Guidance on Travel During the Pandemic Shows Little Progress
item.description: The Omicron variant turned my trip home from South Africa into a nightmare episode of conflicting public health orders that often seemed to have little connection to science.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen

item.title: South Korean City to Test Facial Recognition to Track the Coronavirus
item.description: Officials hope the system can help reveal the movements of people who test positive and their interactions with others, making contact tracing easier.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site in Bucheon, South Korea, last year.

item.title: Israeli Prime Minister Holds Historic Meeting With U.A.E Crown Prince
item.description: Cementing an alliance built on mutual fear of Iran, Prime Minister Naftali Bennett met Prince Mohammed bin Zayed of the United Arab Emirates on the first official visit by an Israeli leader to the Gulf state.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel, left, and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Zayed met in Abu Dhabi on Monday.

item.title: America’s Anti-Democratic Movement
item.description: It’s making progress.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times

item.title: India Cities Ban Eggs, Drawing a Backlash
item.description: Food-cart rules spurred by conservative beliefs draw a backlash, showcasing the tensions around the country’s rising Hindu nationalist movement.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Indian street food vendor preparing an egg dish for a customer in Ahmedabad in the state of Gujarat in November.

item.title: Cultivating Olives on the Slopes of Mount Etna
item.description: For millenniums, farmers and vintners in northeastern Sicily have benefited from the area’s mineral-rich soil, a result of volcanic eruptions.
item.dc:creator: Marta Giaccone

item.title: South Korea Has Long Wanted Nuclear Subs. A New Reactor Could Open a Door.
item.description: The country plans to build a small modular reactor for marine propulsion, raising questions of whether it eventually intends to develop a nuclear submarine despite a U.S. treaty.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: The submarine Dosan Ahn Chang-ho off the coast of Pohang, South Korea, taking part in a celebration of the nation’s 73rd Armed Forces Day in October 2021.

item.title: Across the World, Covid Anxiety and Depression Take Hold
item.description: It is still unclear how much of a threat the fast-spreading Omicron variant poses, but fear and a sudden revival of restrictions have added to an epidemic of loneliness.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: A Covid-19 patient in a hospital in Marseille, France, on Friday.

item.title: Hong Kong Court Sentences Jimmy Lai to Prison Over Tiananmen Vigil
item.description: The former media mogul and other prominent pro-democracy activists were previously convicted of inciting others to take part in an unauthorized assembly.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: A van took Jimmy Lai and other prominent pro-democracy activists to the Wanchai district court in Hong Kong last week for their trial.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Deadly storms in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: An American flag is affixed to a tree trunk on Sunday after a series of tornadoes ripped through the area of Mayfield, Ky.
